4 1841 martin van buren martin van buren be bear in kinderhook columbium county ny December 5 1782 he be the eldest son of abraham van buren a small farmer and of mary hoe -lrb- originally spell go -rrb- whose first husband be name van alen he study the rudiment of english and latin in the school of he native village at the age of 14 year commence reading law in the office of franci sylvester and pursue he legal novitiate for seven year combine with he professional study a fondness for extemporaneous debate he be early note for he intelligent observation of public event and for he interest in politics be choose to participate in a nominating convention when only 18 year old in 1802 go to new york city and study law with william p van ness a friend of aaron burr be admit to the bar in 1803 return to kinderhook and associate himself in practice with he half-brother jame i van alen he be a zealous adherent of jefferson and support morgan lewi for governor of new york in 1803 against aaron burr in February 1807 he marry hannah hoe a distant kinswoman in the winter of 1806-7 remove to hudson the county seat of columbium county and in the same year be admit to practice in the supreme court in 1807 support daniel d tompkin for governor against morgan lewi the latter have come to be consider less true than the former to the measure of jefferson in 1808 become surrogate of columbium county displace he halt-brother and partner who belong to the defeat faction in 1813 on a change of party predominance at albany he half-brother be restore to the office early in 1811 he figure in the council of he party at a convention hold in albany when the propose recharter of the united state bank be the lead question of federal politics though albert gallatin secretary of the treasury have recommend a recharter the predominant sentiment of the republican party be adverse to the measure van buren share in this hostility and publicly laud the spartan firmness of george clinton when as vice-president he give he casting vote in the united state senate against the bank bill February 20 1811 in 1812 be elect to the senate of new york from the middle district as a clinton republican defeat edward p livingston take he seat in November of that year and become thereby a member of the court of error then compose of senator in connection with the chancellor and the supreme court as senator he strenuously oppose the charter of the bank of america which be then seek to establish itself in new york and to take the place of the united state bank though count among the adherent of madison 's administration and though commit to the policy of declare war against great britain he side with the republican member of the new york legislature in 1812 and support de witt clinton for the presidency in the following year however he dissolve he political relation with clinton and resume the _ entente cordiale _ with madison 's administration in 1815 while still a member of the senate be appoint attorney-general of the state supersede the venerable abraham van vechten in 1816 be reelect to the state senate and remove to albany form a partnership with he life-long friend benjamin f butler in the same year be appoint a regent of the university of new york support de witt clinton for governor of new york in 1817 but oppose he reelection in 1820 in 1819 be remove from the office of attorney-general February 6 1821 be elect united state senator in the same year be choose from otsego county as a member of the convention to revise the constitution of the state take he seat in the united state senate December 3 1821 and be at once make a member of its committee on the judiciary and finance for many year be chairman of the former support william h crawford for the presidency in 1824 be reelect to the senate in 1827 but soon resign he seat to accept the office of governor of new york to which he be elect in 1828 be a zealous supporter of andrew jackson in the presidential election of 1828 and in 1829 become premier of the new administration as secretary of state he bring to a favorable close the long-standing feud between the united state and england with regard to the west indium trade resign he secretaryship in June 1831 and be send as minister to england the senate refuse in 1832 to confirm he nomination by the casting vote of john c calhoun the vice-president in 1832 be elect vice-president of the united state and in 1833 come to preside over the body which a year before have reject he as a foreign minister on may 20 1835 be formally nominate for the presidency and be elect in 1836 over he three competitor william h harrison hugh l white and daniel webster by a majority of 57 in the electoral college but of only 25000 in the popular vote on may 5 1840 be nominate for the presidency by the democratic national convention at baltimore md at the election on November 10 be defeat by william henry harrison who receive 234 electoral vote and a popular majority of nearly 140000 van buren receive but 60 vote in the electoral college retire to he country seat lindenwald in he native county be a candidate for the presidential nomination at the democratic national convention at baltimore md may 27 1844 but be defeat by jame k polk be nominate for the presidency by a barnburner convention at utica ny June 22 1848 a nomination which he have decline by letter in advance he be also nominate for the presidency by the free soil national convention of buffalo August 9 1848 at the election November 7 receive only a popular vote of 291263 and no electoral vote support franklin pierce for the presidency in 1852 and jame buchanan in 1856 in 1860 vote the fusion ticket of breckinridge dougla and bell in new york against mr lincoln but when the civil war begin give to the administration he zealous support die at kinderhook July 24 1862 and be bury there inaugural address fellow citizen : the practice of all my predecessor impose on I a obligation i cheerfully fulfill -- to accompany the first and solemn act of my public trust with a avowal of the principle that will guide I in perform it and a expression of my feeling on assume a charge so responsible and vast in imitate they example i tread in the footstep of illustrious man whose superior it be we happiness to believe be not find on the executive calendar of any country among they we recognize the earliest and firmest pillar of the republic -- those by whom we national independence be first declare he who above all other contribute to establish it on the field of battle and those whose expand intellect and patriotism construct improved and perfect the inestimable institution under which we live if such man in the position i now occupy feel themselves overwhelmed by a sense of gratitude for this the highest of all mark of they country 's confidence and by a consciousness of they inability adequately to discharge the duty of a office so difficult and exalted how much more must these consideration affect one who can rely on no such claim for favor or forbearance unlike all who have precede I the revolution that give we existence as one people be achieve at the period of my birth and whilst i contemplate with grateful reverence that memorable event i feel that i belong to a later age and that i may not expect my countryman to weigh my action with the same kind and partial hand so sensibly fellow-citizen do these circumstance press themselves upon I that i should not dare to enter upon my path of duty do i not look for the generous aid of those who will be associate with I in the various and coordinate branch of the government do i not repose with unwavering reliance on the patriotism the intelligence and the kindness of a people who never yet desert a public servant honestly labor in they cause and above all do i not permit myself humbly to hope for the sustain support of a ever-watchful and beneficent providence to the confidence and consolation derive from these source it would be ungrateful not to add those which spring from we present fortunate condition though not altogether exempt from embarrassment that disturb we tranquillity at home and threaten it abroad yet in all the attribute of a great happy and flourishing people we stand without a parallel in the world abroad we enjoy the respect and with scarcely a exception the friendship of every nation at home while we government quietly but efficiently perform the sole legitimate end of political institution -- in do the greatest good to the greatest number -- we present a aggregate of human prosperity surely not elsewhere to be find how imperious then be the obligation impose upon every citizen in he own sphere of action whether limited or extend to exert himself in perpetuate a condition of thing so singularly happy all the lesson of history and experience must be lose upon we if we be content to trust alone to the peculiar advantage we happen to possess position and climate and the bounteous resource that nature have scatter with so liberal a hand -- even the diffused intelligence and elevated character of we people -- will avail we nothing if we fail sacredly to uphold those political institution that be wisely and deliberately form with reference to every circumstance that could preserve or might endanger the blessing we enjoy the thoughtful framer of we constitution legislate for we country as they find it look upon it with the eye of statesman and patriot they see all the source of rapid and wonderful prosperity but they see also that various habit opinion and institution peculiar to the various portion of so vast a region be deeply fix distinct sovereignty be in actual existence whose cordial union be essential to the welfare and happiness of all between many of they there be at least to some extent a real diversity of interest liable to be exaggerate through sinister design they differ in size in population in wealth and in actual and prospective resource and power they vary in the character of they industry and staple production and -lrb- in some -rrb- exist domestic institution which unwisely disturb might endanger the harmony of the whole most carefully be all these circumstance weigh and the foundation of the new government lay upon principle of reciprocal concession and equitable compromise the jealousy which the smaller state might entertain of the power of the rest be allay by a rule of representation confessedly unequal at the time and design forever to remain so a natural fear that the broad scope of general legislation might bear upon and unwisely control particular interest be counteract by limit strictly draw around the action of the federal authority and to the people and the state be leave unimpaired they sovereign power over the innumerable subject embrace in the internal government of a just republic except such only as necessarily appertain to the concern of the whole confederacy or its intercourse as a unite community with the other nation of the world this provident forecast have be verify by time half a century teem with extraordinary event and elsewhere produce astonishing result have pass along but on we institution it have leave no injurious mark from a small community we have rise to a people powerful in number and in strength but with we increase have go hand in hand the progress of just principle the privilege civil and religious of the humblest individual be still sacredly protect at home and while the valor and fortitude of we people have remove far from we the slightest apprehension of foreign power they have not yet induce we in a single instance to forget what be right we commerce have be extend to the remotest nation the value and even nature of we production have be greatly change a wide difference have arise in the relative wealth and resource of every portion of we country yet the spirit of mutual regard and of faithful adherence to exist compact have continue to prevail in we council and never long be absent from we conduct we have learn by experience a fruitful lesson -- that a implicit and undeviating adherence to the principle on which we set out can carry we prosperously onward through all the conflict of circumstance and vicissitude inseparable from the lapse of year the success that have thus attend we great experiment be in itself a sufficient cause for gratitude on account of the happiness it have actually confer and the example it have unanswerably give but to I my fellow-citizen look forward to the far-distant future with ardent prayer and confide hope this retrospect present a ground for still deeper delight it impress on my mind a firm belief that the perpetuity of we institution depend upon ourselves that if we maintain the principle on which they be establish they be destine to confer they benefit on countless generation yet to come and that america will present to every friend of mankind the cheer proof that a popular government wisely form be want in no element of endurance or strength fifty year ago its rapid failure be boldly predict latent and uncontrollable cause of dissolution be suppose to exist even by the wise and good and not only do unfriendly or speculative theorist anticipate for we the fate of past republic but the fear of many a honest patriot overbalance he sanguine hope look back on these foreboding not hastily but reluctantly make and see how in every instance they have completely fail a imperfect experience during the struggle of the revolution be suppose to warrant the belief that the people would not bear the taxation requisite to discharge a immense public debt already incur and to pay the necessary expense of the government the cost of two war have be pay not only without a murmur but with unequaled alacrity no one be now leave to doubt that every burden will be cheerfully bear that may be necessary to sustain we civil institution or guard we honor or welfare indeed all experience have show that the willingness of the people to contribute to these end in case of emergency have uniformly outrun the confidence of they representative in the early stage of the new government when all feel the impose influence as they recognize the unequaled service of the first president it be a common sentiment that the great weight of he character could alone bind the discordant material of we government together and save we from the violence of contend faction since he death nearly forty year be go party exasperation have be often carry to its highest point the virtue and fortitude of the people have sometimes be greatly try yet we system purify and enhance in value by all it have encounter still preserve its spirit of free and fearless discussion blended with unimpaired fraternal feeling the capacity of the people for self-government and they willingness from a high sense of duty and without those exhibition of coercive power so generally employ in other country to submit to all needful restraint and exaction of municipal law have also be favorably exemplify in the history of the american state occasionally it be true the ardor of public sentiment outrun the regular progress of the judicial tribunal or seek to reach case not denounce as criminal by the exist law have display itself in a manner calculate to give pain to the friend of free government and to encourage the hope of those who wish for its overthrow these occurrence however have be far less frequent in we country than in any other of equal population on the globe and with the diffusion of intelligence it may well be hope that they will constantly diminish in frequency and violence the generous patriotism and sound common sense of the great mass of we fellow-citizen will assuredly in time produce this result for as every assumption of illegal power not only wound the majesty of the law but furnish a pretext for abridge the liberty of the people the latter have the most direct and permanent interest in preserve the landmark of social order and maintain on all occasion the inviolability of those constitutional and legal provision which they themselves have make in a suppose unfitness of we institution for those hostile emergency which no country can always avoid they friend find a fruitful source of apprehension they enemy of hope while they foresee less promptness of action than in government differently form they overlook the far more important consideration that with we war could never be the result of individual or irresponsible will but must be a measure of redress for injury sustain voluntarily resort to by those who be to bear the necessary sacrifice who would consequently feel a individual interest in the contest and whose energy would be commensurate with the difficulty to be encounter actual event have prove they error the last war far from impair give new confidence to we government and amid recent apprehension of a similar conflict we see that the energy of we country would not be want in ample season to vindicate its rights we may not possess as we should not desire to possess the extended and ever-ready military organization of other nation we may occasionally suffer in the outset for the want of it but among ourselves all doubt upon this great point have cease while a salutary experience will prevent a contrary opinion from invite aggression from abroad certain danger be foretell from the extension of we territory the multiplication of state and the increase of population we system be suppose to be adapt only to boundary comparatively narrow these have be widen beyond conjecture the member of we confederacy be already double and the number of we people be incredibly augmented the alleged cause of danger have long surpass anticipation but none of the consequence have follow the power and influence of the republic have rise to a height obvious to all mankind respect for its authority be not more apparent at its ancient than it be at its present limit new and inexhaustible source of general prosperity have be open the effect of distance have be avert by the inventive genius of we people develop and foster by the spirit of we institution and the enlarged variety and amount of interest production and pursuit have strengthen the chain of mutual dependence and form a circle of mutual benefit too apparent ever to be overlook in justly balance the power of the federal and state authority difficulty nearly insurmountable arise at the outset and subsequent collision be deem inevitable amid these it be scarcely believe possible that a scheme of government so complex in construction could remain uninjured from time to time embarrassment have certainly occur but how just be the confidence of future safety impart by the knowledge that each in succession have be happily remove overlook partial and temporary evil as inseparable from the practical operation of all human institution and look only to the general result every patriot have reason to be satisfy while the federal government have successfully perform its appropriate function in relation to foreign affair and concern evidently national that of every state have remarkably improve in protect and develop local interest and individual welfare and if the vibration of authority have occasionally tend too much toward one or the other it be unquestionably certain that the ultimate operation of the entire system have be to strengthen all the exist institution and to elevate we whole country in prosperity and renown the last perhaps the greatest of the prominent source of discord and disaster suppose to lurk in we political condition be the institution of domestic slavery we forefather be deeply impressed with the delicacy of this subject and they treat it with a forbearance so evidently wise that in spite of every sinister foreboding it never until the present period disturb the tranquillity of we common country such a result be sufficient evidence of the justice and the patriotism of they course it be evidence not to be mistake that a adherence to it can prevent all embarrassment from this as well as from every other anticipated cause of difficulty or danger have not recent event make it obvious to the slightest reflection that the least deviation from this spirit of forbearance be injurious to every interest that of humanity include amidst the violence of excited passion this generous and fraternal feeling have be sometimes disregard and standing as i now do before my countryman in this high place of honor and of trust i can not refrain from anxiously invoke my fellow-citizen never to be deaf to its dictate perceive before my election the deep interest this subject be begin to excite i believe it a solemn duty fully to make known my sentiment in regard to it and now when every motive for misrepresentation have pass away i trust that they will be candidly weigh and understand at least they will be my standard of conduct in the path before I i then declare that if the desire of those of my countryman who be favorable to my election be gratified i must go into the presidential chair the inflexible and uncompromising opponent of every attempt on the part of congress to abolish slavery in the district of columbium against the wish of the slaveholding state and also with a determination equally decide to resist the slightest interference with it in the state where it exist i submit also to my fellow-citizen with fullness and frankness the reason which lead I to this determination the result authorize I to believe that they have be approve and be confide in by a majority of the people of the united state include those whom they most immediately affect it now only remain to add that no bill conflict with these view can ever receive my constitutional sanction these opinion have be adopt in the firm belief that they be in accordance with the spirit that actuate the venerated father of the republic and that succeed experience have prove they to be humane patriotic expedient honorable and just if the agitation of this subject be intend to reach the stability of we institution enough have occur to show that it have signally fail and that in this as in every other instance the apprehension of the timid and the hope of the wicked for the destruction of we government be again destine to be disappoint here and there indeed scene of dangerous excitement have occur terrifying instance of local violence have be witness and a reckless disregard of the consequence of they conduct have expose individual to popular indignation but neither mass of the people nor section of the country have be swerve from they devotion to the bond of union and the principle it have make sacred it will be ever thus such attempt at dangerous agitation may periodically return but with each the object will be better understand that predominate affection for we political system which prevail throughout we territorial limit that calm and enlighten judgment which ultimately govern we people as one vast body will always be at hand to resist and control every effort foreign or domestic which aim or would lead to overthrow we institution what can be more gratifying than such a retrospect as this we look back on obstacle avoid and danger overcome on expectation more than realize and prosperity perfectly secure to the hope of the hostile the fear of the timid and the doubt of the anxious actual experience have give the conclusive reply we have see time gradually dispel every unfavorable foreboding and we constitution surmount every adverse circumstance dread at the outset as beyond control present excitement will at all time magnify present danger but true philosophy must teach we that none more threatening than the past can remain to be overcome and we ought -lrb- for we have just reason -rrb- to entertain a abide confidence in the stability of we institution and a entire conviction that if administer in the true form character and spirit in which they be establish they be abundantly adequate to preserve to we and we child the rich blessing already derive from they to make we beloved land for a thousand generation that choose spot where happiness spring from a perfect equality of political rights for myself therefore i desire to declare that the principle that will govern I in the high duty to which my country call I be a strict adherence to the letter and spirit of the constitution as it be design by those who frame it look back to it as a sacred instrument carefully and not easily frame remember that it be throughout a work of concession and compromise view it as limit to national object regard it as leave to the people and the state all power not explicitly part with i shall endeavor to preserve protect and defend it by anxiously refer to its provision for direction in every action to matter of domestic concernment which it have intrust to the federal government and to such as relate to we intercourse with foreign nation i shall zealously devote myself beyond those limit i shall never pass to enter on this occasion into a further or more minute exposition of my view on the various question of domestic policy would be as obtrusive as it be probably unexpected before the suffrage of my countryman be confer upon I i submit to they with great precision my opinion on all the most prominent of these subject those opinion i shall endeavor to carry out with my utmost ability we course of foreign policy have be so uniform and intelligible as to constitute a rule of executive conduct which leave little to my discretion unless indeed i be willing to run counter to the light of experience and the known opinion of my constituent we sedulously cultivate the friendship of all nation as the condition most compatible with we welfare and the principle of we government we decline alliance as adverse to we peace we desire commercial relation on equal term be ever willing to give a fair equivalent for advantage receive we endeavor to conduct we intercourse with openness and sincerity promptly avow we object and seek to establish that mutual frankness which be as beneficial in the dealings of nation as of man we have no disposition and we disclaim all right to meddle in dispute whether internal or foreign that may molest other country regard they in they actual state as social community and preserve a strict neutrality in all they controversy well know the try valor of we people and we exhaustless resource we neither anticipate nor fear any design aggression and in the consciousness of we own just conduct we feel a security that we shall never be call upon to exert we determination never to permit a invasion of we rights without punishment or redress in approach then in the presence of my assemble countryman to make the solemn promise that yet remain and to pledge myself that i will faithfully execute the office i be about to fill i bring with I a settle purpose to maintain the institution of my country which i trust will atone for the error i commit in receive from the people the sacred trust twice confide to my illustrious predecessor and which he have discharge so faithfully and so well i know that i can not expect to perform the arduous task with equal ability and success but unite as i have be in he counsel a daily witness of he exclusive and unsurpassed devotion to he country 's welfare agree with he in sentiment which he countryman have warmly support and permit to partake largely of he confidence i may hope that somewhat of the same cheer approbation will be find to attend upon my path for he i but express with my own the wish of all that he may yet long live to enjoy the brilliant evening of he well-spent life and for myself conscious of but one desire faithfully to serve my country i throw myself without fear on its justice and its kindness beyond that i only look to the gracious protection of the divine be whose strengthen support i humbly solicit and whom i fervently pray to look down upon we all may it be among the dispensation of he providence to bless we beloved country with honor and with length of day may she way be way of pleasantness and all she path be peace march 4 1837 the senate and house of representative _ : the act of the 23d of June 1836 regulate the deposit of the public money and direct the employment of state district and territorial bank for that purpose make it the duty of the secretary of the treasury to discontinue the use of such of they as should at any time refuse to redeem they note in specie and to substitute other bank provide a sufficient number could be obtain to receive the public deposit upon the term and condition therein prescribe the general and almost simultaneous suspension of specie payment by the bank in may last render the performance of this duty imperative in respect to those which have be select under the act and make it at the same time impracticable to employ the requisite number of other upon the prescribed condition the specific regulation establish by congress for the deposit and safe-keeping of the public money have thus unexpectedly become inoperative i feel it to be my duty to afford you a early opportunity for the exercise of you supervisory power over the subject i be also lead to apprehend that the suspension of specie payment increase the embarrassment before exist in the pecuniary affair of the country would so far diminish the public revenue that the accrue receipt into the treasury would not with the reserved five million be sufficient to defray the unavoidable expense of the government until the usual period for the meeting of congress whilst the authority to call upon the state for a portion of the sum deposit with they be too restricted to enable the department to realize a sufficient amount from that source these apprehension have be justify by subsequent result which render it certain that this deficiency will occur if additional means be not provide by congress the difficulty experience by the mercantile interest in meet they engagement induce they to apply to I previously to the actual suspension of specie payment for indulgence upon they bond for duty and all the relief authorize by law be promptly and cheerfully grant the dependence of the treasury upon the avail of these bond to enable it to make the deposit with the state require by law lead I in the outset to limit this indulgence to the 1st of September but it have since be extend to the 1st of October that the matter might be submit to you further direction question be also expect to arise in the recess in respect to the October installment of those deposit require the interposition of congress a provision of another act pass about the same time and intend to secure a faithful compliance with the obligation of the united state to satisfy all demand upon they in specie or its equivalent prohibit the offer of any bank note not convertible on the spot into gold or silver at the will of the holder and the ability of the government with million on deposit to meet its engagement in the manner thus require by law be render very doubtful by the event to which i have refer sensible that adequate provision for these unexpected exigency could only be make by congress convince that some of they would be indispensably necessary to the public service before the regular period of you meeting and desirous also to enable you to exercise at the earliest moment you full constitutional power for the relief of the country i could not with propriety avoid subject you to the inconvenience of assemble at as early a day as the state of the popular representation would permit i be sure that i have do but justice to you feeling in believe that this inconvenience will be cheerfully encounter in the hope of render you meeting conducive to the good of the country during the earlier stage of the revulsion through which we have just pass much acrimonious discussion arise and great diversity of opinion exist as to its real cause this be not surprising the operation of credit be so diversified and the influence which affect they so numerous and often so subtle that even precious metal -- a policy the wisdom of which none can doubt though there may be different opinion as to the extent to which it should be carry its result have be already too auspicious and its greatly depreciate and they fluctuate in value between one place and another thus diminish and make uncertain the worth of property and the price of labor and fail to subserve except at a heavy loss the purpose of business with each succeed day the metallic currency decrease by some it be hoard in the natural fear that once part with it can not be replace while by other it be divert from its more be in market without reference to any other circumstance the certainty that the efflux of time would not always in such case and perhaps not even generally furnish a true criterion of value and the probability that person reside in the vicinity as the period for the reduction of price approach would postpone purchase they would otherwise make for the purpose of avail themselves of the lower price with other consideration of a similar character have hitherto be successfully urge to defeat the graduation upon time may not all reasonable desire upon this subject be satisfy without encounter any of these objection all will concede the abstract principle that the price of the public land should be proportion to they relative value so far as can be accomplish without depart from the rule heretofore observe require fixed price in case of private entry the difficulty of the subject seem to lie in the mode of ascertain what that value be would not the safest plan be that which have be adopt by many of the state as the basis of taxation -- a actual valuation of land and classification of they into different rate would it not be practicable and expedient to cause the relative value of the public land in the old district which have be for a certain length of time in market to be appraise and class into two or more rate below the present minimum price by the officer now employ in this branch of the public service or in any other mode deem preferable and to make those price permanent if upon the come in of the report they shall prove satisfactory to congress could not all the object of graduation be accomplish in this way and the objection which have hitherto be urge against it avoid it would seem to I that such a step with a restriction of the sale to limited quantity and for actual improvement would be free from all just exception by the full exposition of the value of the land thus furnished and extensively promulgate person live at a distance would be inform of they true condition and enable to enter into competition with those reside in the vicinity the means of acquire a independent home would be bring within the reach of many who be unable to purchase at present price the population of the new state would be make more compact and large tract would be sell which would otherwise remain on hand not only would the land be bring within the means of a larger number of purchaser but many person possess of greater means would be content to settle on a larger quantity of the poorer land rather than emigrate farther west in pursuit of a smaller quantity of better land such a measure would also seem to be more consistent with the policy of the exist law -- that of convert the public domain into cultivate farm own by they occupant that policy be not best promote by send emigration up the almost interminable stream of the west to occupy in group the best spot of land leave immense waste behind they and enlarge the frontier beyond the means of the government to afford it adequate protection but in encourage it to occupy with reasonable denseness the territory over which it advance and find its best defense in the compact front which it present to the indian tribe many of you will bring to the consideration of the subject the advantage of local knowledge and greater experience and all will be desirous of make a early and final disposition of every disturbing question in regard to this important interest if these suggestion shall in any degree contribute to the accomplishment of so important a result it will afford I sincere satisfaction in some section of the country most of the public land have be sell and the register and receiver have very little to do it be a subject worthy of inquiry whether in many case two or more the state to transfer to they for a reasonable equivalent all the refuse and unsold land and to withdraw the machinery of the federal land office altogether all who take a comprehensive view of we federal system and believe that one of its greatest excellence consist in interfere as little as possible with the internal concern of the state look forward with great interest to this result a modification of the exist law in respect to the price of the public land might also have a favorable influence on the legislation of congress in relation to another branch of the subject many who have not the ability to buy at present price settle on those land with the hope of acquire from they cultivation the means of purchase under preemption law from time to time pass by congress for this encroachment on the rights of the united state they excuse themselves under the plea of they own necessity the fact that they dispossess nobody and only enter upon the waste domain : that they give additional value to the public land in they vicinity and they intention ultimately to pay the government price so much weight have from time to time be attach to these consideration that congress have year after they passage crowd of new settler have be find on the public land for similar reason and under like expectation who have be indulge with the same privilege this course of legislation tend to impair public respect for the law of the country either the law to prevent intrusion upon the public land should be execute or if that should be impracticable or inexpedient they should be modify or repeal if the public land be to be consider as open to be occupy by any they should by law be throw open to all that which be intend in all instance to be legalize should at once be make legal that those who be dispose to conform to the law may enjoy at least equal privilege with those who be not but it be not believe to be the disposition of congress to open the public land to occupancy without regular entry and payment of the government price as such a course must tend to worse evil than the credit system which it be find necessary to abolish it would seem therefore to be the part of wisdom and sound policy to remove as far as practicable the cause which produce intrusion upon the public land and then take efficient step to prevent they in future would any single measure be so effective in remove all plausible grounds for these intrusion as the graduation of price already suggest a short period of industry and economy in any part of we country would enable the poorest citizen to accumulate the means to buy he a home at the lower price and leave he without apology for settle on land not he own if he do not under such circumstance he would enlist no sympathy in he favor and the law would be readily execute without do violence to public opinion a large portion of we citizen have seat themselves on the public land without authority since the passage of the last preemption law and now ask the enactment of another to enable they to retain the land occupy upon payment of the minimum government price they ask that which have be repeatedly grant before if the future may be judge of by the past little harm can be do to the interest of the treasury by yield to they request upon a critical examination it be find that the land sell at the public sale since the introduction of cash payment in 1820 have produce on a average the net revenue of only 6 cent a acre more than the minimum government price there be no reason to suppose that future sale will be more productive the government therefore have no adequate pecuniary interest to induce it to drive these people from the land they occupy for the purpose of sell they to other entertain these view i recommend the have it bring to a speedy and amicable termination this can only be do by measure of mutual forbearance and moderation on the part of both government to this end the effort of the american government have be earnest persevere and constant it have do as it will continue to do everything in its power to induce the state of maine to pursue a course best calculate to avoid all excitement and collision be direct by he government to make the follow observation to mr forsyth secretary of state of the united state with reference to certain point connect with the question of the northeastern boundary which question form the subject of the accompany note which the undersign have the honor this day to address to mr forsyth : the british government with a view to prevail upon that of the united state to come to a understanding with great britain upon the river question have state that the king of the netherland in he award have decide that question accord to the british interpretation of it and have express he opinion that the river which fall into the bay of fundy be not to be consider as atlantic river for the purpose of the treaty mr forsyth however in he note to sir charle vaughan of the 28th of April 1835 controvert this assertion and maintain that the king of the netherland do not in he award express such a opinion and mr forsyth quote a passage from the award in support of this proposition but it appear to she majesty 's government that mr forsyth have not correctly perceive the meaning of the passage which he quote for in the passage in question mr forsyth apprehend that the word _ alone _ be govern by the verb _ include _ whereas a attentive examination of the context will show that the word _ alone _ be govern by the verb _ divide _ and that the real meaning of the passage be this : that the river flow north and south from the highland claim by the united state may be arrange in two genus the first genus comprehend the river which fall into the st lawrence the second genus comprehend those whose water in some manner or other find they way into the atlantic but that even if accord to this general classification and in contradistinction from river flow into the st lawrence the river which fall into the bay of chaleur and fundy might be comprise in the same genus with the river which fall directly into the atlantic still the st john and the restigouche form a distinct species by themselves and do not belong to the species of river which fall _ directly _ into the atlantic for the st john and restigouche be not divide in company with any such last-mentioned river and the award go on to say that moreover if this distinction between the two species be confound a erroneous interpretation would be apply to a treaty in which every separate word must be suppose to have a meaning and a generic distinction would be give to case which be purely specific the above appear to be the true meaning of the passage quote by mr forsyth but if that passage have not be in itself sufficiently explicit which she majesty 's government think it be the passage which immediately follow it would remove all doubt as to what the opinion of the king of the netherland be upon the river question for that passage setting forth reason against the line of boundary claim by the united state go on to say that such line would not even separate the st lawrence river immediately from the st john and restigouche and that thus the river which this line would separate from the st lawrence river would need _ in order to reach the atlantic _ the aid of _ two intermediary _ -- first the river st john and restigouche and _ secondly the bay of chaleur and fundy _ now it be evident from this passage that the king of the netherland deem the bay of fundy and chaleur to be for the purpose of the treaty as distinct and separate from the atlantic ocean as be the river st john and restigouche for he specifically mention those river and those bay as the channel through which certain river would have to pass in they way from the northern range of divide highland down to the atlantic ocean and it be clear that he consider that the water of those highland river would not reach the atlantic ocean until after they have travel through the whole extent either of the restigouche and the bay of chaleur or of the st john and the bay of fundy as the case might be and for this reason among other the king of the netherland declare it to be he opinion that the line north of the st john claim by the united state be not the line intend by the treaty the undersigned avail himself of this occasion to renew to mr forsyth the assurance of he high respect and consideration h fox _ mr fox to mr forsyth _ washington _ January 19 1838 _ hon john forsyth accordance with the principle of equity and in pursuance of the general practice of mankind in similar case the object of difference should be equally divide between the two differ party each of whom be alike convince of the justice of its own claim the united state government have reply that to such a arrangement it have no power to agree that until the line of the treaty shall have be otherwise determine the state of maine will continue to assume that the line which it claim be the true line of 1783 and will assert that all the land up to that line be territory of maine that consequently federal government have no power to agree to such a arrangement without the consent of the state concern she majesty 's government exceedingly regret that such a obstacle should exist to prevent that settlement which under all the circumstance of the case appear to be the simplest the readiest the most satisfactory and the most just nor can she majesty 's government admit that the objection of the state of maine be well found for the principle on which that objection rest be as good for great britain as it be for maine if maine think itself entitle to contend that until the true line describe in the treaty be determine the boundary claim by maine must be regard as the right one great britain be surely still more entitle to insist upon a similar pretension and to assert that until the line destruction of the life of some american citizen who be on board of the boat at the time she be attack the act complain of be do under the follow circumstance : in upper canada which contain a population of about 450000 soul the most perfect tranquillity prevail up to the 4th day of December last although in the adjoining province of lower canada many of the french canadian inhabitant have be in open rebellion against the government for about a month precede at no time since the treaty of peace with the united state in 1815 have upper canada be more undisturbed the real cause of the insurrection in lower canada namely the national antipathy of the french inhabitant do not in any degree apply in the upper province whose population like the british and american inhabitant of lower canada be wholly oppose to the revolt and anxious to render every service in they power in support of the queen 's authority it have be report to the government some time before the 4th of December that in a remote portion of the home district a number of person occasionally meet and drill with arm under leader know to be disaffected but it be not believe by the government that anything more could be intend than to make a show of threaten revolt in order to create a diversion in favor of the rebel in lower canada the feeling of loyalty throughout this province be know to be so prevalent and decide that it be not think unsafe to forbear for the time at least to take any notice of the proceedings of this party on the night of the 4th December the inhabitant of the city of toronto be alarm by the intelligence that about 500 person arm with rifle be approach the city that they have murder a gentleman of great respectability in the highway and have make several person prisoner the inhabitant rush immediately to arm there be no soldier in the province and no militia have be call out the home district from which this party of armed man come contain 60000 inhabitant the city of toronto 10000 in a few hour a respectable force although undisciplined be collect and arm in self-defense and await the threaten attack it seem now to admit of no doubt that if they have at once advance against the insurgent they would have meet with no formidable resistance but it be think more prudent to wait until a sufficient force should be collect to put the success of a attack beyond question in the meantime people pour in from all quarter to oppose the insurgent who obtain no increase of number but on the contrary be desert by many of they body in consequence of the act of devastation and plunder into which they leader have force they on the 7th of December a overwhelming force of militia go against they and disperse they without lose a man take many prisoner who be instantly by my order release and suffer to depart to they home the rest with they leader flee some have since surrender themselves to justice many have be take and some have escape from the province it be report about this time that in the district of london a similar disposition to rise have be observe and in consequence a militia force of about 400 man be send into that district where it be speedily join by three time as many of the inhabitant of the district who assemble voluntarily and come to they aid with the greatest alacrity it be discover that about 300 person under dr duncombe a american by birth be assemble with arm but before the militia could reach they they disperse themselves and flee of these by far the greater come in immediately and submit themselves to the government declare that they have be mislead and deceive and pray for forgiveness in about a week perfect tranquillity be restore and from that moment not a man have be see in arm against the government in any part of the province with the exception of the hostile aggression upon navy island which i shall presently notice nor have there be the slightest resistance offer to the execution of legal process in a single instance after the dispersion of the armed insurgent near toronto mr mckenzie they leader escape in disguise to the niagara river and cross over to buffalo report have be spread there and elsewhere along the american frontier that toronto have be burnt and that the rebel be completely successful but the falsehood of these absurd rumor be well know before mckenzie arrive on the american side it be know also that the ridiculous attempt of 400 man to revolutionize a country contain nearly half a million inhabitant have be put down by the people instantly and decidedly without the loss of a man nevertheless a number of american citizen in buffalo and other town on the frontier of the state of new york enlist as soldier with the avowed object of invade canada and establish a provisional government public meeting be hold to forward this design of invade a country with which the united state be at peace volunteer be call for and arm ammunition and provision be supply by contribution openly make all this be in direct and flagrant violation of the express law of the united state as well as of the law of nation the civil authority of buffalo offer some slight shew of resistance to the movement be urge to interpose by many of the most respectable citizen but no real impediment be offer and on the 13th of December some hundred of the citizen of the state of new york as a armed body under the command of a mr van rensselaer a american citizen openly invade and take possession of navy island a part of upper canada situate in the niagara river not believe that such a outrage would really be commit no force whatever be assemble at the time to counteract this hostile movement in a very short time this lawless band obtain from some of the arsenal of the state of new york -lrb- clandestinely as it be say -rrb- several piece of artillery and other arm which in broad daylight be openly transport to navy island without resistance from the american authority the people of buffalo and the adjacent country continue to supply they with store of various kind and additional man enlist in they rank in a few day they force be variously state from 500 to 1500 of whom a small proportion be rebel who have flee from upper canada they begin to intrench themselves and threaten that they would in a short time make a landing on the canadian side of the niagara river to prevent this and to keep they in check a body of militia be hastily collect and station on the frontier under the command of colonel cameron assistant adjutant-general of militia who be succeed in any rights but it would express and declare we view and intention such a survey be not a warlike or offensive movement and can not justly give offense to the other party in the controversy it be the unquestionable right of litigant in a court of justice to make exploration of land in dispute and if either party decline a joint survey it may be make _ ex parte _ and surely the united state have never so far yield the actual possession to great britain as to preclude the right on we part to ascertain for ourselves the absolute fact and to mark out the limit of we claim and we alleged right this act maine ask and ask earnestly the general government to perform without delay such a assumption of the controversy on the part of the united state would be to maine a assurance that she rights be duly regard and would be steadily and perseveringly maintain we want the name and the authority of the united state and there can be no doubt that a act emanate from that source would be regard by those interested on both side as of more importance than any act of a individual state so far then from any indifference on the part of maine as to the action of the general government or any desire to be drive to assume the performance of the duty allude to she look with intense anxiety and confident hope to be relieve from this position she believe it be alike due to the honor of the united state and the rights of maine that the general government should go forward in the work and that there be less to apprehend in the result from such a course than any other but maine feel that the time for decisive action have come that she can not be satisfy to have the claim to absolute and exclusive jurisdiction of a large part of she territory longer tolerate and acquiesce in she know that it rightfully belong to she jurisdiction that it be hers by a clear perfect and honest title -- as clear as perfect and rightful as she title to any portion of the state -- and she can not consent to have this title impaired or weaken by bold encroachment and unscrupulous demand she can not consent that a title transmit by the father of the revolution shall be destroy or defeat by acquiescence in the adverse occupation of a foreign state and that what be once fairly yield shall be reclaim in utter defiance of a solemn deed of cession i be confident i be not mistake in state that the legislature of maine consider the question as fairly and plainly before the national government and that if the present session of congress should close with a denial or postponement of the propose survey and no commission should be create by the executive as contemplate in the resolution refer to we should have a right and be bind to regard such a delay or refusal as evidence of a indisposition on the part of the general government to accede to we express view and wish and a denial of justice and that maine in that event owe it to herself to cause the survey to be make under she own authority the duty of the executive of maine be plainly point out and make imperative and absolute by the resolve of the legislature and i certainly can not hesitate so far as i have the means and power to execute they declare will the people of maine sir be not desirous of conflict or war both in they habit and they principle they love and wish for peace and quiet within they border they be satisfactory and acquiesce in by this state but that we should neither ask nor agree that any preliminary point should be yield by either party we should only ask that the treaty should be place in they hand with direction to ascertain and run and fix the line accord to its plain language and obvious meaning maine can never consent as i apprehend to yield the main point of the case and then refer it to enable the judge to divide the subject-matter of the controversy we feel that we now stand on the high vantage ground of truth and justice and that it can not be that any nation profess to act on the principle of right and equity can stand up before the civilized world and contest with unyielding pertinacity we claim we have too much respect for the nation from which we descend to believe that she will sully she reputation by such persevere resistance i be conscious that the language and style of this communication be unusual and probably undiplomatic that there be more of the fervor of feeling and the plain language of direct appeal than be usual in such papers but it be a subject of such vast importance to the state whose interest have be in part intrust to I and whose organ i be that i can not speak in measure term or indefinite language on this subject we have no ulterior view and no conceal object we plan and we policy be open and expose to the view of all man maine have nothing in either to conceal or disguise she plainly and distinctly ask for specific and definite action in perform what i conceive to be my duty i have be actuate by entire respect toward the general government and by the single desire to explain and enforce as well as i be able we wish and we rights i can only add that we trust the general government will assume the performance of the washington _ December 3 1838 _ _ fellow-citizen of the senate and house of representative _ : i congratulate you on the favorable circumstance in the condition of we country under which you reassemble for the performance of you official duty though the anticipation of a abundant harvest have not everywhere be realize yet on the whole the labor of the husbandman be reward with a bountiful return industry prosper in its various channel of business and enterprise general health again prevail through we vast diversity of climate nothing threaten from abroad the continuance of external peace nor have anything at home impair the strength of those fraternal and domestic tie which constitute the only guaranty to the success and permanency of we happy union and which form in the hour of peril have hitherto be honorably sustain through every vicissitude in we national affair these blessing which evince the care and beneficence of providence call for we devout and fervent gratitude we have not less reason to be grateful for other bounty bestow by the same munificent hand and more exclusively we own the present year close the first half century of we federal institution and we system differ from all other in the acknowledged practical and unlimited operation which it have for so long a period give to the sovereignty of the people have now be fully test by experience the constitution devise by we forefather as the framework and bond of that system then untried have become a settled form of government not only preserve and protect the great principle upon which it be found but wonderfully promote individual happiness and private interest though subject to change and entire revocation whenever deem inadequate to all these purpose yet such be the wisdom of its construction and so stable have be the public sentiment that it remain unaltered except in matter of detail comparatively unimportant it have prove amply sufficient for the various emergency incident to we condition as a nation a formidable foreign war agitate collision between domestic and in some respects rival sovereignty temptation to interfere in the intestine commotion of neighbor country the dangerous influence that arise in period of excessive prosperity and the antirepublican tendency of associate wealth -- these with other trial not less formidable have all be encounter and thus far successfully resist it be reserve for the american union to test the advantage of a government entirely dependent on the continual exercise of the popular will and we experience have show that it be as beneficent in practice as it be just in theory each successive change make in we local institution have contribute to extend the right of suffrage have increase the direct influence of the mass of the community give greater freedom to individual exertion and restricted more and more the power of government yet the intelligence prudence and patriotism of the people have keep pace with this augmented responsibility in no country have education be so widely diffused domestic peace have nowhere so largely reign the close bond of social intercourse have in no instance prevail with such harmony over a space so vast all form of religion have unite for the first time to diffuse charity and piety because for the first time in the history of nation all have be totally untrammeled and absolutely free the deepest recess of the wilderness have be penetrate yet instead of the rudeness in the social condition consequent upon such adventure elsewhere numerous community have spring up already unrivaled in prosperity general intelligence internal tranquillity and the wisdom of they political institution internal improvement the fruit of individual enterprise foster by the protection of the state have add new link to the confederation and fresh reward to provident industry doubtful question of domestic policy have be quietly settle by mutual forbearance and agriculture commerce and manufacture minister to each other taxation and public debt the burden which bear so heavily upon all other country have press with comparative lightness upon we without one entangle alliance we friendship be prize by every nation and the rights of we citizen be everywhere respect because they be know to be guard by a unite sensitive and watchful people to this practical operation of we institution so evident and successful we owe that increase attachment to they which be among the most cheer exhibition of popular sentiment and will prove they best security in time to come against foreign or domestic assault this review of the result of we institution for half a century without exciting a spirit of vain exultation should serve to impress upon we the great principle from which they have spring -- constant and direct supervision by the people over every public measure strict forbearance on the part of the government from exercise any doubtful or disputed power and a cautious abstinence from all interference with concern which properly belong and be best leave to state regulation and individual enterprise full information of the state of we foreign affair have be recently on different occasion submit to congress i deem it necessary now to bring to you notice only such event as have subsequently occur or be of such importance as to require particular attention the most amicable disposition continue to be exhibit by all the nation with whom the government and citizen of the united state have a habitual intercourse at the date of my last annual message mexico be the only nation which could not be include in so gratify a reference to we foreign relation i be happy to be now able to inform you that a advance have be make toward the adjustment of we difference with that republic and the restoration of the customary good feeling between the two nation this important change have be effect by conciliatory negotiation that have result in the conclusion of a treaty national treasury for the first time since the establishment of the government by judicial compulsion exercise by the common-law writ of mandamus issue by the circuit court of this district the fact of the case and the grounds of the proceedings will be find fully state in the report of the decision and any additional information which you may desire will be supply by the proper department no interference in the particular case be contemplate the money have be pay the claim of the prosecutor have be satisfied and the whole subject so far as they be concerned be finally dispose of but it be on the supposition that the case may be regard as a authoritative exposition of the law as it now stand that i have think it necessary to present it to you consideration the object of the application to the circuit court be to compel the postmaster-general to carry into effect a award make by the solicitor of the treasury under a special act of congress for the settlement of certain claim of the relator on the post-office department which award the postmaster-general decline to execute in full until he should receive further legislative direction on the subject if the duty impose on the postmaster-general by that law be to be regard as one of a official nature belong to he office as a branch of the executive then it be obvious that the constitutional competency of the judiciary to direct and control he in its discharge be necessarily draw in question and if the duty so impose on the postmaster-general be to be consider as merely ministerial and not executive it yet remain to be show that the circuit court of this district have authority to interfere by mandamus such a power have never before be assert or claim by that court with a view to the settlement of these important question the judgment of the circuit court be carry by a writ of error to the supreme court of the united state in the opinion of that tribunal the duty impose on the postmaster-general be not a official executive duty but one of a merely ministerial nature the grave constitutional question which have be discuss be therefore exclude from the decision of the case the court indeed expressly admit that with power and duty properly belong to the executive no other department can interfere by the writ of mandamus and the question therefore resolve itself into this : have congress confer upon the circuit court of this district the power to issue such a writ to a officer of the general government command he to perform a ministerial act a majority of the court have decide that it have but have found they decision upon a process of reasoning which in my judgment render further legislative provision indispensable to the public interest and the equal administration of justice it have long since be decide by the supreme court that neither that tribunal nor the circuit court of the united state hold within the respective state possess the power in question but it be now hold that this power deny to both of these high tribunal -lrb- to the former by the constitution and to the latter by congress -rrb- have be by its legislation vest in the circuit court of this district no such direct grant of power to the circuit court of this district be claim but it have be hold to result by necessary implication from several section of the law establish the court one of these section declare that the law of maryland as they exist at the time of the cession should be in force in that part of the district cede by that state and by this provision the common law in civil and criminal case as it prevail in maryland in 1801 be establish in that part of the district in england the court of king 's bench -- because the sovereign who accord to the theory of the constitution be the fountain of justice originally sit there in person and be still deem to be present in construction of law -- alone possess the high power of issue the writ of mandamus not only to inferior jurisdiction and corporation but also to magistrate and other command they in the king 's name to do what they duty require in case where there be a vested right and no other specific remedy it have be hold in the case refer to that as the supreme court of the united state be by the constitution render incompetent to exercise this power and as the circuit court of this district be a court of general jurisdiction in case at common law and the highest court of original jurisdiction in the district the right to issue the writ of mandamus be incident to its common-law power another ground rely upon to maintain the power in question be that it be include by fair construction in the power grant to the circuit court of the united state by the act to provide for the more convenient organization of the court of the united state pass 13th February 1801 that the act establish the circuit court of this district pass the 27th day of February 1801 confer upon that court and the judge thereof the same power as be by law vest in the circuit court of the united state and in the judge of the say court that the repeal of the first-mentioned act which take place in the next year do not divest the circuit court of this district of the authority in dispute but leave it still clothe with the power over the subject which it be concede be take away from the circuit court of the united state by the repeal of the act of 13th February 1801 admit that the adoption of the law of maryland for a portion of this district confer on the circuit court thereof in that portion the transcendent extrajudicial prerogative power of the court of king 's bench in england or that either of the act of congress by necessary implication authorize the former court to issue a writ of mandamus to a officer of the united state to compel he to perform a ministerial duty the consequence be in one respect the same the result in either case be that the officer of the united state station in different part of the united state be in respect to the performance of they official duty subject to different law and a different supervision -- those in the state to one rule and those in the district of columbium to another and a very different one in the district they official conduct be subject to a judicial control from which in the state they be exempt whatever difference of opinion may exist as to the expediency of vest such a power in the judiciary in a system of government constitute like that of the united state all must agree that these disparage discrepancy in the law and in the administration of justice ought not to be permit to continue and as congress alone can provide the remedy the subject be unavoidably present to you consideration m van buren special message washington that the two government have differ not only in regard to the main question of title to the territory in dispute but with reference also to the right of jurisdiction and the fact of the actual exercise of it in different portion thereof always aim at a amicable adjustment of the dispute both party have entertain and repeatedly urge upon each other a desire that each should exercise its rights whatever it consider they to be in such a manner as to avoid collision and allay to the greatest practicable extent the excitement likely to grow out of the controversy it be in pursuance of such a understanding that maine and massachusett upon the remonstrance of great britain desist from make sale of land and the general government from the construction of a project military road in a portion of the territory of which they claim to have enjoy the exclusive possession and that great britain on she part in deference to a similar remonstrance from the united state suspend the issue of licens to cut timber in the territory in controversy and also the survey and location of a railroad through a section of country over which she also claim to have exercise exclusive jurisdiction the state of maine have a right to arrest the depredation complain of it belong to she to judge of the exigency of the occasion call for she interference and it be presume that have the lieutenant-governor of new brunswick be correctly advise of the nature of the proceedings of the state of maine he would not have regard the transaction as require on he part any resort to force each party claim a right to the territory and hence to the exclusive jurisdiction over it it be manifest that to prevent the destruction of the timber by trespasser act against the authority of both and at the same time avoid forcible collision between the contiguous government during the pendency of negotiation concern the title resort must be have to the mutual exercise of jurisdiction in such extreme case or to a amicable and temporary arrangement as to the limit within which it should be exercise by each party the understanding suppose to exist between the united state and great britain have be find heretofore sufficient for that purpose and i believe will prove so hereafter if the party on the frontier directly interested in the question be respectively govern by a just spirit of conciliation and forbearance if it shall be find as there be now reason to apprehend that there be in the mode of construe that understanding by the two government a difference not to be reconcile i shall not hesitate to propose to she britannic majesty 's government a distinct arrangement for the temporary and mutual exercise of jurisdiction by means of which similar difficulty may in future be prevent but between a effort on the part of maine to preserve the property in dispute from destruction by intruder and a military occupation by that state of the territory with a view to hold it by be take i can not think it proper to invoke the attention of congress to other than amicable means for the settlement of the controversy or to cause the military power of the federal government to be bring in aid of the state of maine in any attempt to effect that object by a resort to force on the other hand if the authority of new brunswick should attempt to enforce the claim of exclusive in regard to the agent of the province of new brunswick i have also recommend that any militia that may have be bring together by the state of maine from a apprehension of a collision with the government or people of the british province will be voluntarily and peaceably disband i can not allow myself to doubt that the result anticipate from these representation will be seasonably realize the party more immediately interested can not but perceive that a appeal to arm under exist circumstance will not only prove fatal to they present interest but would postpone if not defeat the attainment of the main object which they have in view the very incident which have recently occur will necessarily awaken the government to the importance of promptly adjust a dispute by which it be now make manifest that the peace of the two nation be daily and imminently endanger this expectation be further warrant by the general forbearance which have hitherto characterize the conduct of the government and people on both side of the line in the uniform patriotism of maine she attachment to the union she respect for the wish of the people of she sister state -lrb- of whose interest in she welfare she can not be unconscious -rrb- and in the solicitude feel by the country at large for the preservation of peace with we neighbor we have a strong guaranty that she will not disregard the representative _ : i regret that i can not on this occasion congratulate you that the past year have be one of unalloyed prosperity the ravages of fire and disease have painfully afflict otherwise flourish portion of we country and serious embarrassment yet derange the trade of many of we city but notwithstanding these adverse circumstance that general prosperity which have be heretofore so bountifully bestow upon we by the author of all good still continue to call for we warmest gratitude especially have we reason to rejoice in the exuberant harvest which have lavishly recompense well-directed industry and give to it that sure reward which be vainly seek in visionary speculation i can not indeed view without peculiar satisfaction the evidence afford by the past season of the benefit that spring from the steady devotion of the husbandman to he honorable pursuit no means of individual comfort be more certain and no source of national prosperity be so sure nothing can compensate a people for a dependence upon other for the bread they eat and that cheerful abundance on which the happiness of everyone so much depend be to be look for nowhere with such sure reliance as in the industry of the agriculturist and the bounty of the earth with foreign country we relation exhibit the same favorable aspect which be present in my last annual message and afford continued proof of the wisdom of the pacific just and forbear policy adopt by the first administration of the federal government and pursue by its successor the extraordinary power vest in I by a act of congress for the defense of the country in a emergency consider so far probable as to require that the executive should possess ample means to meet it have not be exert they have therefore be attend with no other result than to increase by the confidence thus repose in I my obligation to maintain with religious exactness the cardinal principle that govern we intercourse with other nation happily in we pend question with great britain out of which this unusual grant of authority arise nothing have occur to require its exertion and as it be about to return to the legislature i trust that no all circumstance to the line of duty and to satisfy they of the safety with which a course really right and demand by a financial crisis may in a community like ours be pursue however apparently severe its immediate operation the policy of the federal government in extinguish as rapidly as possible the national debt and subsequently in resist every temptation to create a new one deserve to be regard in the same favorable light among the many objection to a national debt the certain tendency of public security to concentrate ultimately in the coffer of foreign stockholder be one which be every day gathering strength already have the resource of many of the state and the future industry of they citizen be indefinitely mortgage to the subject of european government to the amount of twelve million annually to pay the constantly accrue interest on borrow money -- a sum exceed half the ordinary revenue of the whole united state the pretext which this relation afford to foreigner to scrutinize the management of we domestic affair if not actually to intermeddle with they present a subject for earnest attention not to say of serious alarm fortunately the federal government with the
