have fully and faithfully pay all its creditor have also relieve itself entirely from debt to maintain a distinction so desirable and so honorable to we national character should be a object of earnest solicitude never should a free people if it be possible to avoid it expose themselves to the necessity of have to treat of the peace the honor or the safety of the republic with the government of foreign creditor who however well disposed they may be to cultivate with we in general friendly relation be nevertheless by the law of they own condition make hostile to the success and permanency of political institution like ours most humiliating may be the embarrassment consequent upon such a condition another objection scarcely less formidable to the commencement of a new debt be its inevitable tendency to increase in magnitude and to foster national extravagance he have be a unprofitable observer of event who need at this day to be admonish of the difficulty which a government habitually dependent on loan to sustain its ordinary expenditure have to encounter in resist the influence constantly exert in favor of additional loan by capitalist who enrich themselves by government security for amount much exceed the money they actually advance -- a prolific source of individual aggrandizement in all borrow country by stockholder who seek they gain in the rise and fall of public stock and by the selfish importunity of applicant for appropriation for work avowedly for the accommodation of the public but the real object of which be too frequently the advancement of private interest the known necessity which so many of the state will be under to impose tax for the payment of the interest on they debt furnish a additional and very cogent reason why the federal government should refrain from create a national debt by which the people would be expose to double taxation for a similar object we possess within ourselves ample resource for every emergency and we may be quite sure that we citizen in no future exigency will be unwilling to supply the government with all the means ask for the defense of the country in time of peace there can at all event be no justification for the creation of a permanent debt by the federal government its limited range of constitutional duty may certainly under such circumstance be perform without such a resort it have it be see be avoid during four year of greater fiscal difficulty than have exist in a similar period since the adoption of the constitution and one also remarkable for the occurrence of extraordinary cause of expenditure but to accomplish so desirable a object two thing be indispensable : first that the action of the federal government be keep within the boundary prescribe by its founder and secondly that all appropriation for object admit to be constitutional and the expenditure of they also be subject to a standard of rigid but well-considered and practical economy the first depend chiefly on the people themselves -- the opinion they form of the true construction of the constitution and the confidence they repose in the political sentiment of those they select as they representative in the federal legislature the second rest upon the fidelity with which they more immediate representative and other public functionary discharge the trust commit to they the duty of economize the expense of the public service be admit on all hand yet there be few subject upon which there exist a wider difference of opinion than be constantly manifest in regard to the fidelity with which that duty be discharge neither diversity of sentiment nor even mutual recrimination upon a point in respect to which the public mind be so justly sensitive can well be entirely avoid and least so at period of great political excitement a intelligent people however seldom fail to arrive in the end at correct conclusion in such a matter practical economy in the management of public affair can have no adverse influence to contend with more powerful than a large surplus revenue and the unusually large appropriation for 1837 may without doubt independently of the extraordinary this work the party be employ until the 14th September it have now arrive at a point where the magalloway river should be find to the leave accord to the most authentic map of the country especially that prepare by the new hampshire commissioner appoint in 1836 to explore the boundary of that state and accompany that report -lrb- 90 -rrb- the party accordingly bear well north to avoid be lead from the true height of land by the divide ridge between the connecticut and androscoggin river after cross several small stream it come on the afternoon of the 15th to a rivulet about 12 foot wide run to the east which be suppose to be the main magalloway the 16th be spend in explore it to its source the next day it be discover that what have be take for the magalloway be a tributary of salmon river a large branch of the st franci and consequently the party be considerably to the north of the boundary the supply of provision do not allow the party to retrace its step to the point where it have diverge from the true divide ridge the course be therefore change until it bear a little south but it be not until the 22d that the party find itself again on the divide ridge and then upon the water of the magalloway the party reach arnold river or chaudiere above lake megantic on the 24th September after have recruit and take a fresh supply of provision from the depot establish there the party be divide into two detachment one return westward to find the corner of the state of new hampshire as mark by the commission in 1789 appoint to trace the boundary line it be there ascertain that the corner be on the true _ divide _ ridge and not from 8 to 10 mile south as have be erroneously report by the surveyor employ by the new hampshire commissioner in 1836 and reiterate in several official papers from the state corner the divide ridge be follow to where it have be previously explore by the party thence a course be take to the northeast so as to reach the head of lake megantic and thence to lake magaumac where on the 8th October the two detachment be again unite the detachment lead by the assistant mr cutt have successfully follow the divide ridge from the camp of the 24th on arnold river to this place it be now ascertain that the provision remain be not sufficient to subsist all of the company until the kennebec road could be reach by follow the _ height of land _ it be think advisable again to separate into two detachment -- one to follow the ridge supply with provision for twenty day and the other to strike for the nearest settlement which it be suppose could be reach in four or five day this movement commence on the 10th October and the detachment follow the high land reach the kennebec road on the 23d and on the follow day provision for the party for fifteen day be place there and a like quantity at the mouth of the metjarmette it be intend that the two detachment should move simultaneously from these two point on the 26th to explore the boundary line as far as lake etchemin a deep snow which commence fall on the night of the 25th compel the commissioner to abandon further exploration at that time and there be not the slightest probability that they could be resume before another year the result of these exploration may be state as follow : about 160 mile of country along or near the _ height of land _ have be traverse the travel distance carefully estimate and the course measure with a compass barometrical observation be make as often as necessary for give a profile of the route from the head of hall stream to arnold or the chaudiere river and thence to lake magaumac via the corner of the state of new hampshire some further barometrical observation be make between the lake and the kennebec road but for a portion of that distance the barometer be unserviceable in consequence of air have enter the tube astronomical observation be make as often as there be a opportunity but owe to the prevalence of cloud not as often as be desirable they will serve for correct the course and estimate distance travel barometrical observation for comparison be make at the intersection of the kennebec road and height of land hourly from 7 be to 5 pm while the party be on the divide ridge the only discovery of interest make by this party be that the magalloway river do not head any of the branch of the connecticut as it be generally believe it do and consequently we claim to hall stream be deprive of the support it would have have from the fact that _ all _ the other branch be head by a atlantic river and consequently could not be reach by the line along the height of land from the northwest angle of nova scotium the other commissioner -lrb- major graham -rrb- do not receive he appointment until 16th August to fill the place leave vacant by the nonacceptance of professor cleaveland and to he be assign the survey and examination of the due north line commence at the source of the river st croix and extend to the highland which divide the water that flow into the river st lawrence from those which flow into the atlantic ocean immediately after receive he appointment he take the necessary step for organize he party and in addition to two officer of the corps of topographical engineer assign to he by the commandant of the corps for this service he call to he aid two civil engineer possess the requisite qualification for the duty to be perform so soon as the requisite instrument could be procure and put in proper order he leave new york for portland I where he arrive on the 5th of September expect there to join he colleague of the commission they have however proceed to the point designate for the commencement of they respective duty the season be too far advance to justify they incur any further delay at portland a short conference be have with mr stubb the agent of the state department who furnish the necessary means for procure a outfit for the party in provision camp equipage etc the party then proceed to bangor where it be occupy until the 12th in procure the necessary supplies of provision camp equipage transportation etc to enable it to take the field and a few astronomical observation be make here for the purpose of test the rate of the chronometer which be to be use upon this service as well as of obtain additional datum for compute the longitude of this place which together with the latitude have be determine by the commissioner by a very near approximation in the summer of 1838 while occupy upon the military reconnoissance of the northeastern frontier on the 12th the party leave bangor for houlton where it arrive on the evening of the 13th a depot of provision be establish here for supply the line of they future operation and the service of the requisite number of man as axmen chain bearer instrument carrier etc be engage pend these preparation and the time necessarily occupy in cut a roadway through the forest from a convenient point on the calai road to the monument at the source of the river st croix a series of astronomical observation be make both by day and by night by which the latitude and longitude of houlton be satisfactorily determine and the rate of the chronometer further test by the 24th of September the roadway be sufficiently open to permit a camp to be establish upon the experimental line trace by the united state and british surveyor in the year 1817 when a attempt be make to mark this portion of the boundary between the two country agreeably to the provision of the treaty of ghent of 1815 the provision and camp equipage be transport upon a strong but roughly construct sled draw by horse whilst the instrument be carry by hand the surface of the country over which this roadway be open be too rough for any wheel vehicle to pass the point decide upon as the true source of the river st croix by the united state and british commissioner appoint for that purpose under the fifth article of the treaty of 1794 be find and identify both by the inscription upon the monument erect there to mark the spot and also by the testimony of a living witness of high respectability who have know the locality since it be first designate by the commissioner under the treaty of 1794 the avenue which have be clear through a dense forest from the monument to a distance of 12 mile north of it by the surveyor in 1817 be easily recognize by the new and thick growth of young timber which have a width of from 40 to 50 foot now occupy it axmen be at once set at work to reopen this avenue under the supposition that the due north line would at least fall within its border for a distance of 12 mile in the meantime the first astronomical station and camp be establish and the transit instrument set up at a distance of 4578 foot north of the monument upon a eminence 45-1\/2 foot above the level of its base this position command a distinct view of the monument to the south and of the whole line to the north for a distance of 11 mile reach to park hill whilst the work of clear the line of its young growth of timber be progress a series of astronomical observation be commence at this first camp and continue both day and night without intermission -lrb- except when interrupt by unfavorable weather -rrb- with the sextant the repeat circle of reflection and the transit instrument until the latitude and longitude of the monument and of this first camp be satisfactorily ascertain and also the direction of the true meridian from the say monument establish for this latter purpose several observation be in the first place make upon the polar star -lrb- -lrb- greek : alpha -rrb- ursa minori -rrb- when at its greatest eastern diurnal elongation and the direction thus obtain be afterwards verify and correct by numerous transit observation upon star pass the meridian at various altitude both north and south of the zenith these be multiply with every degree of care and with the aid of four excellent chronometer whose rate be constantly test not only by the transit observation but also by equal altitude of the sun in the day to correct the time at noon and midnight and by observe altitude of east and west star for correct the same at various hour of the night the direction of this meridian as thus establish by the commissioner be find to vary from the experimental line trace by the surveyor of 1817 by run in the first place to the west of they line then cross it and afterwards deviate considerably to the east of it at the second principal station erect by the party distant 6 mile and 3952 foot north of the first camp or 7 mile and 3240 foot north of the monument it find itself 60 foot to the west of the line of 1817 this appear to be the maximum deviation to the west of that line as near as its trace could be identify which be only mark by permanent object recognize by the party at the termination of each mile from the monument soon after pass this station the line of 1817 be cross and the party do not afterwards touch it but deviate more and more to the east of it as it progress north by a irregular proportion to the distance advance in order to obtain a correct profile or vertical section along the whole extent of this meridian line in the hope of furnish datum for accurate comparison of elevation so far as they might be consider relevant to the subject in dispute between the two government and also to afford a accurate base of comparison for the barometer along a extended line which must traverse many ridge that will be object of minute exploration for many mile of lateral extent a officer be detail to trace a line of level from the base of the monument mark the source of the river st croix to tide water at calai in maine by which mean the elevation of the base of the monument above the plane of mean low and mean high water and also the elevation of several intermediate point of the river st croix on its expand lake surface have be accurately ascertain another officer be at the same time charge with trace a line of level from the base of the same monument along the due north line as mark by the commissioner by which it be intend that every undulation with the absolute height above the plane of mean low water at calai shall be show along the whole extent of that line at park hill distant only 12 mile from the monument a second station for astronomical observation be establish and a camp suitable for that purpose be form on the 26th day of October whilst occupy in complete the prolongation of the meridian line to that point and in establish a camp there the party be visit by a snowstorm which cover the ground to a depth of 4 inch in the course of six hour this be succeed by six day of dark stormy weather which entirely interrupt all progress and terminate by a rain with a change to a milder temperature which clear away the snow during this untoward event the party make themselves as comfortable as practicable in they tent and be occupy in compute many of the astronomical and other observation previously make on the 2d of November the weather become clear and the necessary astronomical observation be immediately commence at park hill from this elevated point the first station could be distinctly see by means of small heliotrope during the day and bright light erect upon it at night its direction with that of several intermediate station due south of park hill be verify by a new series of transit observation upon high and low star both north and south of the zenith by the same mean the line be prolong to the north in one week after commence the observation at park hill the weather become again unfavorable the sky be so constantly overcast as to preclude all astronomical observation and the atmosphere so thick as to prevent a view to the north which would permit new station to be establish with sufficient accuracy in that direction unwilling to quit the field while there be a prospect of the weather become sufficiently favorable to enable the party to reach the latitude of mar hill or even proceed beyond it it be determine that some of the party should continue in the tent and there occupy themselves with such calculation as ought to be make before quit the field the officer charge with the line of level and with the reconnoissance in advance for the selection of new position for station continue they labor in the field notwithstanding they be frequently expose to slight rain and snow storm as these portion of the work could go on without a clear sky on the 13th of November a severe snowstorm occur which in a single night and a portion of the follow morning cover the surface of the whole country and the roof of the tent to a depth of 16 inch the northern extremity of the avenue which have be clear by the surveyor of 1817 be now reach and in addition to the young growth which have spring up since that period upon the previous part of the line several mile have be clear through the dense forest of heavy timber in order to proceed with the line of level which have reach nearly to the meduxnakeag the depth of snow now upon the ground render it impracticable to continue the level with the requisite accuracy any further and that part of the work be accordingly suspend for the season the thermometer have long since assume a range extend during the night and frequently during a great portion of the day to many degree below the freezing point the highland border on the aroostook distant 40 mile to the north of the party be distinctly see from a elevated position whenever the atmosphere be clear and a long extent of intermediate country of inferior elevation to the position then occupy present itself to the view with the two peak of mar hill rise abruptly above the general surface which surround they base the eastern extremity of the base of the easternmost peak be nearly 2 degree of arc or nine-tenth of a mile in space to the west of the line as it pass the same latitude to erect station opposite to the base of mar hill and upon the height of the aroostook in order to obtain exact comparison with the old line at these point be consider object of so much importance as to determine the commissioner to continue the operation in the field to the latest practicable period in hope of accomplish these end on the 18th day of November the party succeed in erect a station opposite mar hill and very near the meridian line it be thus prove that the line would pass from nine-tenth of a mile to 1 mile east of the eastern extremity of the base of the northeast peak of mar hill on the 30th of November a series of signal be commence to be interchange at night between the position of the transit instrument on park hill and the highland of the aroostook these be continue at interval whenever the weather be sufficiently clear until by successive approximation a station be on the 9th of December establish on the height 1 mile south of that river and on the meridian line the point thus reach be more than 50 mile from the monument at the source of the st croix as ascertain from the land survey make under the authority of the state of maine and massachusett the measurement of the party could not be extend to this last point owe to the depth of the snow which lay upon the ground since the middle of November but the distance derive from the land survey must be a very near approximation to the truth a permanent station be erect at the position establish on the aroostook height and a measurement make from it due west to the experimental or explore line of 1817 by which the party find itself 2400 foot to the east of that line between the 1st and 15th of December the observation be carry on almost exclusively during the night and frequently with the thermometer range from 0 to 10 and 12 degree below that point by fahrenheit 's scale although frequently expose to this temperature in the performance of they duty in the open air at night and to within a few degree of that temperature during the hour of sleep with no other protection than the tent and camp bed commonly use in the army the whole party both officer and man enjoy excellent health during the day the tent in which the astronomical computation be carry on be render quite comfortable by means of small stove but at night the fire would become extinguish and the temperature reduce to within a few degree of that of the outward air within the observatory tent the comfort of a fire could not be indulge in in consequence of the too great liability to produce serious error of observation by the smoke pass the field of the telescope the astronomical observation be therefore always make in the open air or in a tent open to the heaven at top during the hour of observation and without a fire on the 16th of December the tent be strike and this party retire from the field for the season there be then more than 2 foot of snow on the ground to the unremitting zeal amidst severe exposure and to the scientific and practical attainment of the officer both civil and military who serve under the order of the commissioner on this duty he acknowledge himself in a great measure indebted for the progress that he be enable to make notwithstanding the many difficulty encounter observation be make during portion of three lunation of the transit of the moon 's bright limb and of such tabulated star as differ but little in right ascension and declination from the moon in order to obtain additional datum to those furnish by chronometrical comparison with the meridian of boston for compute the longitude of this meridian line at the first station 4578 foot north of the monument and also at the park hill station the dip of the magnetic needle be ascertain by a series of observation -- in the one case upon two and in the other upon three separate needle the horizontal declination be also ascertain at both these station by a full set of observation upon six different needle the detail of these and of all the astronomical observation allude to will be prepare as soon as practicable for the use of the commission should they be require to he excellency major-general sir john harvey kcb lieutenant-governor of the province of new brunswick major graham acknowledge himself greatly indebted for have in the most obliging manner extend to him-every facility within he power for prosecute the examination from mr connell of woodstock a member of the colonial parliament and from lieutenant-colonel maclauchlan the british land agent very kind attention be receive major graham have also great pleasure in acknowledge he obligation to general eusti commandant of the eastern department to colonel pierce command the garrison at houlton and to he officer and also to major ripley of the ordnance department command the arsenal at augusta for the prompt and oblige manner in which they supply many article useful to the prosecution of the labor of he party the transit instrument with which the meridian line be trace have be loan to the commission by the hon william a duer president of columbium college new york and the commissioner feel bind to return they acknowledgment for the liberality with which the use of this astronomical instrument be grant at a time when it would have be difficult and perhaps impossible to have procure one as well suit to the object all which be
